title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Chronicles chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Chronicles Chapter 28.

questions.question: How old was Ahaz when he began to reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years old
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:1 states that Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: What kind of images did Ahaz make according to 2 Chronicles 28?
questions.correctAnswer: Molten images for Baalim
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:2 says Ahaz made molten images for Baalim.

questions.question: True or False: Ahaz burnt his children in the fire after the abominations of the heathen.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:3 clearly states that Ahaz burnt his children in the fire after the abominations of the heathen.

questions.question: Where did Ahaz burn incense besides the high places and hills?
options: In the valley of Hinnom only
questions.correctAnswer: Under every green tree
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:4 states that Ahaz burnt incense in the high places, hills, and under every green tree.

questions.question: Which king delivered Ahaz into his hand, leading to a great slaughter?
questions.correctAnswer: King of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:5 states Ahaz was delivered into the hand of the king of Israel, who smote him with a great slaughter.

questions.question: How many valiant men did Pekah son of Remaliah kill in one day?
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:6 mentions Pekah slew 120,000 valiant men in one day.

questions.question: Who was the prophet that spoke to the Israelite army at Samaria?
questions.correctAnswer: Oded
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:9 identifies Oded as the prophet who went before the host that came to Samaria.

questions.question: True or False: The Israelite army decided to keep the captives of Judah as bondmen and bondwomen.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:11 shows the prophet Oded urged them to return the captives to avoid the fierce wrath of the LORD.

questions.question: What did the Ephraimite leaders do with the captives and spoil?
options: Clothed and cared for the captives and returned them
questions.correctAnswer: Clothed and cared for the captives and returned them
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:15 explains the named men took care of the captives, giving them clothing, food, and brought them to Jericho.

questions.question: To whom did Ahaz send for help during his reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:16 states Ahaz sent to the kings of Assyria for help.

questions.question: Which cities did the Philistines take during Ahaz's reign?
options: Bethshemesh, Ajalon, Gederoth, Shocho, Timnah, Gimzo
questions.correctAnswer: Bethshemesh, Ajalon, Gederoth, Shocho, Timnah, Gimzo
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:18 lists these cities as taken by the Philistines.

questions.question: True or False: Ahaz made high places in every city of Judah to burn incense to other gods.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:25 states Ahaz made high places in every city of Judah to burn incense to other gods.

questions.question: Who reigned in Ahaz's place after he died?
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah his son
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:27 says Hezekiah, Ahaz's son, reigned after him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ahaz cut in pieces the vessels of the house of God, shut up the doors of the house of the LORD, and made him altars in every ______ of Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: corner
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:24 specifically says Ahaz made altars in every corner of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What did Ahaz do when he saw the gods of the kings of Syria helped them?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificed to those gods
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:23 states Ahaz sacrificed to the gods of Damascus because he thought they would help him.

medium.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God during hardship and asks what the passage teaches about reliance on God rather than worldly alliances. Based on 2 Chronicles 28, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trust in God rather than seeking help from foreign powers
Seek alliances quickly for immediate help
Ignore prayers and focus on political strategies
Depend on your own strength only
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God rather than seeking help from foreign powers
questions.explanation: Ahaz sent to the kings of Assyria for help instead of relying on God, which led to distress and no true strengthening (2 Chronicles 28:16, 20-21). This teaches us to trust God rather than worldly powers in times of trouble.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 28 teach us about obedience to God's commands through the example of King Ahaz's actions?
options: Obedience to God leads to blessing, disobedience to hardship
Ignoring God's commands shows spiritual strength
Sacrifices to other gods are acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God leads to blessing, disobedience to hardship
questions.explanation: Ahaz did not do what was right before the LORD, walked in the ways of Israel's kings, and worshiped idols, which caused God to deliver Judah into enemies' hands (2 Chronicles 28:1-4, 5-6, 19). This shows the consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: What does the response of the Ephraimite leaders in 2 Chronicles 28 teach us about forgiveness and reconciliation within the community of believers?
options: They urged releasing captives and caring for them despite past sins
They encouraged keeping captives as slaves
questions.correctAnswer: They urged releasing captives and caring for them despite past sins
questions.explanation: The leaders of Ephraim opposed slavery of Judah's captives and instead clothed, fed, anointed, and helped them return home, showing mercy and reconciliation (2 Chronicles 28:9-15).

questions.question: A believer asks how to deal with temptation to rely on false gods when feeling desperate. What biblical principle about faithfulness can you share from 2 Chronicles 28?
options: Faithfulness to the true God is essential even in distress
False gods can provide help if you sacrifice to them
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to the true God is essential even in distress
questions.explanation: Ahaz sacrificed to the gods of Damascus seeking help, but they became his ruin (2 Chronicles 28:22-23). This teaches that faithfulness to God is vital, especially during trials.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 28 emphasize the importance of personal devotion and spiritual discipline in family life?
options: Disobedience leads to the sacrifice of children and family ruin
Spiritual discipline can be ignored for political gain
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to the sacrifice of children and family ruin
questions.explanation: Ahaz burned his children in the fire after the abominations of the heathen and provoked God's anger (2 Chronicles 28:3, 25), showing how disobedience and idolatry damage family life.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and repentance can be learned from the military defeats of Judah in 2 Chronicles 28?
options: God humbles those who forsake Him to lead them to repentance
questions.correctAnswer: God humbles those who forsake Him to lead them to repentance
questions.explanation: Judah was delivered into enemies' hands because they forsook the LORD (2 Chronicles 28:5-6, 19). These defeats serve as a call to humility and repentance.

questions.question: A believer asks how to practice generosity according to 2 Chronicles 28 when seeing others in need. What example can you point to from this chapter?
options: Clothing, feeding, and caring for captives shows true generosity
Taking spoil without mercy is righteous
Being generous only to friends is enough
questions.correctAnswer: Clothing, feeding, and caring for captives shows true generosity
questions.explanation: The leaders of Ephraim clothed, fed, anointed, and assisted the captives, demonstrating generosity and kindness even to former enemies (2 Chronicles 28:14-15).

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 28 teach about honesty and integrity in devotion to God?
options: Integrity requires exclusive worship of the LORD without idolatry
Integrity allows for worship of many gods
Honesty is not important in religious practice
Compromise with false gods is acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity requires exclusive worship of the LORD without idolatry
questions.explanation: Ahaz made altars to other gods and burned incense on high places, violating God's commands (2 Chronicles 28:4, 24-25). True integrity means exclusive worship of God.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 28, Ahaz was buried in the sepulchres of the kings of Israel because of his faithfulness to God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ahaz was not buried in the sepulchres of the kings because he did not follow God, showing judgment even in death (2 Chronicles 28:27).

questions.question: True or False: The prophet Oded encouraged the captors to keep the captives as slaves to increase their power.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Oded urged the captors to release the captives because of the fierce wrath of the LORD and their own sins (2 Chronicles 28:9-11).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ahaz took a portion out of the ______ and gave it to the king of Assyria, but he helped him not.
questions.correctAnswer: house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Ahaz took a portion out of the house of the LORD, the king's house, and the princes and gave it to Assyria, but received no help (2 Chronicles 28:21).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with perseverance through trials and asks how 2 Chronicles 28 teaches endurance. What practical application can you share?
options: Endure by maintaining faithfulness even when facing defeat and hardship
questions.correctAnswer: Endure by maintaining faithfulness even when facing defeat and hardship
questions.explanation: Despite defeat, the chapter emphasizes the consequences of forsaking God and the need to return to Him, encouraging perseverance in faith (2 Chronicles 28:5-7, 19-22).

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 28 illustrate the importance of humility and contentment in leadership and personal life?
options: Ahaz’s pride led to idolatry and ruin, showing the need for humility
Leaders should act without regard to God
questions.correctAnswer: Ahaz’s pride led to idolatry and ruin, showing the need for humility
questions.explanation: Ahaz’s disobedience and idolatry stemmed from pride and lack of humility, resulting in ruin (2 Chronicles 28:22-24), teaching leaders to be humble and content before God.

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 28 teach about the role of prayer and seeking God's guidance in times of national crisis?
options: Seeking God’s help is essential rather than relying on foreign alliances
Prayer is unnecessary if you have strong armies
Foreign alliances replace the need for God’s guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking God’s help is essential rather than relying on foreign alliances
questions.explanation: Ahaz sent for help from Assyria instead of seeking God, which led to distress (2 Chronicles 28:16, 20-21). This encourages believers to seek God's guidance in crises.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 28 emphasize the importance of stewardship and honoring God with what belongs to Him?
options: Taking from the house of the LORD for personal or political gain brings judgment
It is acceptable to use God’s things for worldly purposes
God does not care about how His things are used
questions.correctAnswer: Taking from the house of the LORD for personal or political gain brings judgment
questions.explanation: Ahaz took a portion from the house of the LORD and gave it to Assyria, but he was not helped and faced God's judgment (2 Chronicles 28:21), teaching proper stewardship.

hard.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Chronicles Chapter 28.

questions.question: What specific idolatrous practice did Ahaz adopt that was particularly abominable and linked to the heathen customs previous to Israel's settlement?
options: Burning his children in the fire
Making graven images of the LORD
Offering peace offerings at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Burning his children in the fire
questions.explanation: According to 2 Chronicles 28:3, Ahaz burnt his children in the fire, following abominations of the heathen whom the LORD had cast out before Israel, indicating a direct adoption of forbidden pagan practices.

questions.question: Which foreign king delivered Judah into captivity because of Ahaz's disobedience?
questions.correctAnswer: King of Syria
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that the LORD delivered Ahaz into the hand of the king of Syria, who smote him and took captives to Damascus, showing the consequences of Ahaz's reign.

questions.question: How many valiant men did Pekah son of Remaliah kill in one day, as recorded in this chapter?
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:6 records Pekah killing 120,000 valiant men in Judah in one day, emphasizing the severity of Judah's military losses due to forsaking the LORD.

questions.question: Which prophet intervened to stop the Israelites from enslaving the captives taken from Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Oded
questions.explanation: Verse 9 introduces Oded, a prophet who challenged the Israelites to release the captives, highlighting prophetic calls for mercy and justice.

questions.question: What was the response of the Ephraimite leaders to the prophet Oded's message regarding the captives?
options: They refused to bring the captives into Samaria
They sacrificed the captives to their gods
They sent the captives to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: They refused to bring the captives into Samaria
questions.explanation: According to 2 Chronicles 28:13, the Ephraimite heads opposed bringing the captives, fearing adding to their sins, a recognition of corporate guilt and divine wrath.

questions.question: What acts of kindness were shown to the captives after they were released, as described in this chapter?
options: They were clothed, fed, anointed, and transported on asses
They were sent back naked and hungry
They were offered to other nations for ransom
They were made servants of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They were clothed, fed, anointed, and transported on asses
questions.explanation: Verse 15 explains that the captives received clothing, food, anointing, and were carried on asses, which demonstrates a compassionate restoration contrary to typical wartime practices.

questions.question: To whom did King Ahaz send for help during his time of distress?
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Assyria
questions.explanation: Verse 16 records Ahaz seeking assistance from the kings of Assyria, reflecting the political alliances and dependencies characteristic of the Near Eastern geopolitics.

questions.question: What cities did the Philistines capture in Judah according to this chapter?
options: Bethshemesh, Ajalon, Gederoth, Shocho, Timnah, Gimzo
questions.correctAnswer: Bethshemesh, Ajalon, Gederoth, Shocho, Timnah, Gimzo
questions.explanation: Verse 18 lists these cities as captured by the Philistines, illustrating Judah's territorial losses during Ahaz's reign.

questions.question: What was Tilgathpilneser king of Assyria's effect on Ahaz?
options: He distressed Ahaz but did not strengthen him
He conquered Judah and deposed Ahaz
He formed a lasting alliance with Ahaz
questions.correctAnswer: He distressed Ahaz but did not strengthen him
questions.explanation: Verse 20 explains that although Tilgathpilneser came against Ahaz, he did not provide the help Ahaz sought, indicating political manipulation and failure of Ahaz's reliance on foreign powers.

questions.question: What did Ahaz do with the vessels of the house of God during his reign?
options: He cut them in pieces and shut the temple doors
He purified them and rededicated the temple
He sent them as tribute to the king of Israel
He hid them to protect them from invaders
questions.correctAnswer: He cut them in pieces and shut the temple doors
questions.explanation: Verse 24 records Ahaz's desecration of the temple by destroying sacred vessels and closing the temple, symbolizing his apostasy and rejection of proper worship.

questions.question: What reason did Ahaz give for sacrificing to the gods of Damascus?
options: Because he believed these gods helped the kings of Syria
Because he wanted to unite Judah and Syria religiously
Because the LORD commanded him to
questions.correctAnswer: Because he believed these gods helped the kings of Syria
questions.explanation: Verse 23 shows Ahaz's rationale was that since the gods of Syria helped their kings, he would sacrifice to them hoping for their aid, demonstrating syncretism and misplaced trust.

questions.question: How did the author of 2 Chronicles characterize Ahaz’s overall relationship with the LORD?
options: He did not do what was right in the sight of the LORD
He faithfully followed the covenant of David
questions.correctAnswer: He did not do what was right in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 1 clearly states that Ahaz did not do what was right like David his father, setting the tone for his unfaithful reign.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter states that Ahaz was buried among the kings of Israel in their sepulchres.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 27 specifies that Ahaz was not buried with the kings of Israel, indicating his dishonorable status due to his apostasy.

questions.question: Which thematic element does the account of releasing the captives in this chapter emphasize in the broader biblical narrative?
options: Restoration and mercy as a corrective to oppression
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration and mercy as a corrective to oppression
questions.explanation: The release and care for captives (verses 9-15) reflect the biblical theme of mercy and restoration, contrasting with the typical brutality of war and showing God's desire for compassion among His people.

questions.question: What is an example of Ahaz's syncretism as described in this chapter?
options: Sacrificing to the gods of Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificing to the gods of Damascus
questions.explanation: Verse 23 illustrates Ahaz's syncretism by sacrificing to foreign gods to seek their favor, a violation of exclusive Yahweh worship.

theological.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Chronicles Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for the LORD delivering King Ahaz into the hands of his enemies according to 2 Chronicles 28?
options: Because he did not do what was right in the sight of the LORD
Because he was weak in battle
Because he refused to pay tribute
questions.correctAnswer: Because he did not do what was right in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:1-5 shows Ahaz's disobedience through idolatry and evil practices, leading God to deliver him into enemy hands. This aligns with Deuteronomy 28:15, which teaches disobedience brings defeat. Romans 1:18-32 and Galatians 6:7 confirm God's judgment on sin, and Psalm 7:11 emphasizes God as a righteous judge.

questions.question: What abominable act did King Ahaz commit that reflected the detestable practices of heathen nations?
options: Burning his children in the fire
Offering sacrifices only at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Burning his children in the fire
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:3 states Ahaz burned his children in the fire, mimicking the abominations of the nations God had cast out. This violates the command in Leviticus 18:21 and is condemned in Jeremiah 7:31 and Deuteronomy 12:31. Hebrews 11:37 references such persecutions and sacrifices rejected by God.

questions.question: According to the chapter, what was the consequence for Judah after forsaking the LORD their God?
options: They were defeated by Israel and Syria, losing many captives
They prospered and expanded their territory
They made peace with all their neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: They were defeated by Israel and Syria, losing many captives
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:5-8 describes Judah's defeat because they forsook the LORD, resulting in slaughter and captivity. This echoes Judges 2:11-15 and Isaiah 1:4-9 where sin brings national judgment. Romans 1:24-26 confirms that God gives over those who reject Him to consequences.

questions.question: What role did the prophet Oded play after the defeat of Judah?
options: He urged the captors to release the captives
He prophesied further destruction on Judah
He called for more war against Judah
He led a rebellion against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He urged the captors to release the captives
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:9-11 shows Oded confronting the Israelites with their own sin and urging them to free the captives. This reflects the prophetic call to repentance and mercy seen in Isaiah 1:17 and Jeremiah 22:3. Luke 4:18 highlights Jesus' fulfillment of prophetic mercy and liberation.

questions.question: How did the leaders of Ephraim respond to the prophet Oded's message?
options: They prevented the captives from being brought into Samaria and cared for them
They ignored the prophet and kept the captives
They demanded ransom for the captives
questions.correctAnswer: They prevented the captives from being brought into Samaria and cared for them
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:12-15 records Ephraimite leaders opposing the captivity, fearing further sin, and providing for the captives' needs. This echoes God's justice and mercy (Micah 6:8), and Jesus' teaching in Matthew 25:35-40 about caring for the vulnerable.

questions.question: What foreign power did Ahaz seek help from during his distress?
questions.correctAnswer: Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:16 and 20 show Ahaz sending to the kings of Assyria for help. This reliance on foreign powers rather than trusting God is condemned in Isaiah 30:1-3 and Jeremiah 17:5. Proverbs 3:5-6 emphasizes trusting in the LORD over human alliances.

questions.question: What was the spiritual consequence of Ahaz giving treasures from the house of the LORD to the king of Assyria?
options: He did not receive help and further sinned against the LORD
He was honored by all the nations
He was healed of all diseases
questions.correctAnswer: He did not receive help and further sinned against the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:21-22 says Ahaz took treasures from the temple to Assyria but was not helped and trespassed more against God. This reflects the folly of trusting idols or foreign powers over God (Psalm 20:7, Isaiah 31:1). John 14:6 declares Jesus as the only true help and salvation.

questions.question: What false rationale did Ahaz give for sacrificing to the gods of Damascus?
options: Because the gods of the kings of Syria help them
Because he wanted peace with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because the gods of the kings of Syria help them
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:23 states Ahaz sacrificed to Syrian gods thinking they would help him, but they ruined him. This reflects the error of syncretism and trusting false gods (Exodus 20:3-5, Psalm 115:4-8). Acts 4:12 confirms salvation is found only in the true God through Christ.

questions.question: What did Ahaz do with the vessels of the house of God and the temple doors?
options: He cut them in pieces and shut the doors
He gave them as offerings to the LORD
He stored them safely for future use
questions.correctAnswer: He cut them in pieces and shut the doors
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:24 records Ahaz desecrating the temple by destroying sacred vessels and closing the doors, symbolizing rejection of true worship. This contrasts with 1 Kings 8:10-11 where the temple is honored, and Hebrews 9:11-14 which speaks of Christ as the true High Priest and sanctuary.

questions.question: What did Ahaz establish in Jerusalem and throughout Judah that provoked the LORD to anger?
options: High places to burn incense to other gods
questions.correctAnswer: High places to burn incense to other gods
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:24-25 shows Ahaz made altars in every corner and high places for idolatry, provoking God’s anger. This violates Deuteronomy 12:2-3 and Jeremiah 32:35. True worship requires exclusive devotion to God (Exodus 20:3, John 4:23-24).

questions.question: How did Ahaz’s reign come to an end, and who succeeded him?
options: He died and was buried in Jerusalem; his son Hezekiah reigned after him
He was killed in battle; his brother succeeded him
He abdicated and went into exile; a priest took over
He was overthrown by the people; a foreign king ruled
questions.correctAnswer: He died and was buried in Jerusalem; his son Hezekiah reigned after him
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:27 states Ahaz died and was buried in Jerusalem (not in the royal tombs), and Hezekiah his son became king. This succession is important for the Messianic line (2 Kings 18:1-3). Hebrews 7:14-17 speaks of the royal priesthood and lineage of Christ through David’s descendants.

questions.question: What theological theme is illustrated by God’s repeated deliverance of Judah into captivity due to Ahaz’s sin?
options: God’s righteous judgment on sin and the call to repentance
God’s abandonment of His people without hope
God’s unconditional blessing regardless of behavior
God’s silence in the face of idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: God’s righteous judgment on sin and the call to repentance
questions.explanation: The whole chapter reveals God’s justice in punishing sin (2 Chronicles 28:5-7) but also the opportunity for repentance and mercy (28:9-15). This matches Deuteronomy 30:1-3, Isaiah 55:7, and 2 Peter 3:9. Romans 2:5-11 teaches God’s judgment is just and purposeful.

questions.question: How does Ahaz’s idolatry reflect humanity’s tendency to reject God’s sovereignty?
options: He sought help from foreign gods and made altars to them, ignoring the LORD
He prayed faithfully and trusted God alone
He followed all the commands of the Mosaic law
He restored the temple worship fully
questions.correctAnswer: He sought help from foreign gods and made altars to them, ignoring the LORD
questions.explanation: Ahaz’s actions (28:23-25) show rejecting God's sovereignty in favor of false gods, illustrating human sinfulness and rebellion (Romans 1:21-23). Isaiah 45:5 declares God’s exclusive sovereignty, and 1 Corinthians 10:14 warns against idolatry.

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about the consequences of political alliances based on idolatry rather than faith in God?
options: Such alliances bring distress and ruin, not deliverance
They guarantee military success and peace
They are blessed by God if done wisely
They are neutral with no spiritual impact
questions.correctAnswer: Such alliances bring distress and ruin, not deliverance
questions.explanation: Ahaz’s alliance with Assyria (28:16, 20-21) and worship of Syrian gods led to distress and no real help. Isaiah 31:1 warns against trusting Egypt and Assyria rather than God. Psalm 20:7 contrasts trust in God with trust in horses and chariots. Jeremiah 17:5 speaks of the curse on those trusting in man.

questions.question: What does the intervention of Ephraim's leaders in caring for Judah's captives demonstrate about God’s mercy?
options: God’s mercy extends even to enemies and calls for compassion
God’s mercy is limited to one’s own nation
God’s mercy requires strict punishment without forgiveness
God’s mercy is only shown through judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy extends even to enemies and calls for compassion
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 28:12-15 shows Ephraimite leaders acting mercifully to captives, reflecting God’s mercy (Exodus 34:6-7). Jesus teaches loving enemies and showing mercy (Matthew 5:44, Luke 6:35). The parable of the Good Samaritan (Luke 10:25-37) models such compassion.
